required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Study of Induction Therapy With Mitoxantrone and Plasmapheresis to Treat Aggressive Multiple Sclerosis
clinical_study.official_title: Study of Combinative Effect of Induction Therapy With Mitoxantrone and Plasmapheresis to Treat Patients With Aggressive Multiple Sclerosis

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this study is to compare the effect of combinative induction therapy with mitoxantrone and plasmapheresis versus induction therapy with mitoxantrone alone in cases of aggressive multiple sclerosis

primary_outcome.time_frame: At the end of month 8 after treatment initiation
primary_outcome.description: The Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) is a method of quantifying disability in multiple sclerosis and defines functional systems as pyramidalm, cerebellar, brainstem, sensory, bowel and bladder, visual, cerebral and others. The EDSS scale ranges from 0 to 10 in 0.5 unit increments that represent higher levels of disability.

primary_outcome.measure: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of MS Plaques Found on Brain MRI
primary_outcome.description: Change From Baseline in Mean Number of MS plaques found on Brain MRI 8 months after treatment initiation

arm_group.description: Monthly Plasmapheresis (plasma exchange machine: Haemonetics, model TCS2, USA) 25 ml/kg for 5 cycles, with replacement of 0.9% saline and 5% human serum albumin followed by monthly IV infusion of 12 mg/m2 mitoxantrone (EBEWE Pharma, Amsterdam, The Netherlands) at the end of each Plasmapheresis course for three successive months. Then, treatment is continued by adding two more 6 mg/m2 doses of mitoxantrone in 3-month intervals.

Monthly IV infusion of 12 mg/m2 mitoxantrone (EBEWE Pharma, Amsterdam, The Netherlands) for three successive months. Then, treatment is continued by adding two more 6 mg/m2 doses of mitoxantrone in 3-month intervals.

intervention.description: 3 courses of plasmapheresis are performed before mitoxantrone injection in first 3 months to investigate the efficacy of plasmapheresis in comparison with the other arm that are only treated with mitoxantrone

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Aggressive multiple sclerosis in attack phase
- EDSS: 1-5
- No contraindication for mitoxantrone prescription
- No past history of mitoxantrone injection
- No history of corticosteroid and immunosuppressive therapy in last 3 months
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patient's incompliance
- Severe drug induced side effects

group.title: Mitoxantrone and Plasmapheresis
group.description: Monthly plasmapheresis (plasma exchange machine: Haemonetics, model TCS2, USA) 25 ml/kg for 5 cycles, with replacement of 0.9% saline and 5% human serum albumin followed by monthly IV infusion of 12 mg/m2 mitoxantrone (EBEWE Pharma, Amsterdam, The Netherlands) at the end of each plasmapheresis course for three successive months to investigate the efficacy of plasmapheresis in comparison with the other arm that are only treated with mitoxantrone. Then, treatment is continued by adding two more 6 mg/m2 doses of mitoxantrone in 3-month intervals.

group.title: Mitoxantrone
group.description: Monthly IV infusion of 12 mg/m2 mitoxantrone (EBEWE Pharma, Amsterdam, The Netherlands) for three successive months. Then, treatment is continued by adding two more 6 mg/m2 doses of mitoxantrone in 3-month intervals.

outcome.description: The Kurtzke Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) is a method of quantifying disability in multiple sclerosis and defines functional systems as pyramidalm, cerebellar, brainstem, sensory, bowel and bladder, visual, cerebral and others. The EDSS scale ranges from 0 to 10 in 0.5 unit increments that represent higher levels of disability.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
